ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We met twice per week during a live virtual lecture.
Virtual lecture/seminar
Lectures were also recorded
Readings and zoom classes.
None
The live lectures were recorded as well.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was exposed to so many different fields that fall under the umbrella of Cognitive Science, and learned to engage with each of them in different ways.
Exposure to various faculty in cognitive science-related fields, including economics, psychology, philosophy, neuroscience, and computer science.
Learned about a variety of cognitive science studies/research happening at yale.
I learned about some neat research at Yale and decided on a thesis topic
I learned about the wide variety of research pursuits that exist within cogsci.

So many! This class was amazing! We heard from people in all the constituent fields of cog sci and heard about their research/asked questions. It was awesome to gain some familiarity with so many varied topics.
Critical thinking regarding other people's scientific work
A survey of the various disciplines in the Cognitive Science field and the work being done at Yale

I learned about the variety of ways that cognitive science can be applied in different fields of research. I learned which professors can be contacted for working on a senior project in cognitive science and how to begin my senior project.

I learned a lot about the different areas of research in cognitive science- it opened my eyes to more possibilities and disciplines than I had ever considered before. It also showed me just how interdisciplinary some of the research could be.
Learned more about what the field of cognitive science research actually entails.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I absolutely loved the chance to meet researchers who teach at both the undergraduate and graduate levels, and would love to see this continue in the future of the course.

Strengths: attentive prof and TF, each speaker is excited to come present
Weaknesses: could be better organized by subject area or theme
Encourage more active participation during lectures, give more feedback from each the assignments.
This course isn't super helpful for people who already have a thesis topic
I think I tried to be engaged in the readings which helped me formulate questions for the people presenting in class!

Strengths: All of the wonderful lecturers! The lectures were unique and opened my eyes to areas of cogsci that I had never previously studied.

Weaknesses: I understand the reasoning for a 9 am mandatory class, but differences in time zones made this class time unbearable. At some point we were told that lectures would be recorded for students in different time zones, but I only ever saw a few of those lectures posted. As a result, I wasn't always as present as I would've liked to be during lectures. I regret not being able to fully engage with the lecture topics each class.

I think the presenters should try to perhaps engage students a bit more and create more opportunities for conversation.  It was really cool to learn from these professors but sometimes it felt very one sided.
It's a really fun course. Definitely, one of the most fun I have taken since it's a lot about discovering new areas of study.
The course was the perfect balance between the amount of administrative information and intellectual exploration. I enjoyed hearing from a different professor and field each class.
Guest lectures back to back, to back to back. You peep into many worlds.
I thought that having readings + short responses due before class made me more engaged with the presenters the next day.

Strengths: Mentally prepares you for the kind of work you'll have to do for your capstone, both in terms of research and asking professors to supervise it. 
Weaknesses: Students don't have input on the schedule of speakers so it seemed like the disciplines and subtopics represented in the syllabus reflected the balance of class interests pretty poorly. Also I really think this course should not be in junior fall  if you come out of this class, which is the most in depth intro to the field you can get, realizing that you've picked the wrong major, it's too late to switch. It'd be better if it happened sophomore spring after the intro class and applications to the major have just been accepted.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish that the professor had asked students to turn on their cameras-- I felt so sorry for speakers who came and had to stare into a sea of cameras turned off.
The lectures themselves were generally great and well organized but could've been better organized.
I think the course instructor and TF did a really excellent job this semester!

No special practices were put in place for this class.

Lectures were recorded, but only a few were posted to Canvas.
Some lecturers used Zoom polls.
Prof Knobe was awesome at asking students and presenters questions and getting them to talk even over zoom.
I wish it would have been in person but it was still good.
I was engaged with the course even though everything was virtual.
I thought that having polls during presentations made me more engaged.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Even if this were not a required course for the major, I would absolutely recommend it! The speakers presented on a fascinating array of topics and were eager to engage with students.
You have to take this course if you major in cognitive science.
Yep! I learned a lot about cognitive science research in the process.
It is required
Yes! You get a chance to listen to experts in their field and ask them questions about their research!

This is a mandatory class for juniors majoring in cognitive science.
The lectures were interesting, and I'd recommend explicitly emailing the prof if you're struggling with time zone differences, in order to truly appreciate what you're learning.
Yes!! Amazing class.
Yes, since it is so fun and engaging.
This is a required course for cognitive science majors, but I would still recommend it even if it was not because of the amount of research you get to hear about.
Required, but still maybe, yes?
No, but you're only taking it because it's required.
